name: 政治生態學研討
goals: Understand and critically discuss theories on political ecology, nature conservation and traditional ecological knowledge systems.
Be familiar with the negative effects of development interventions, land grabbing, economic development and nature conservation on local and indigenous peoples.
Map the different stakeholders and governance regimes involved in nature conservation and rural development from  a political ecology perspective.
Evaluate the sustainability of ‘bottom-up’ nature conservation programs across various geographical contexts.
syllabus:
\[The course is in English, but please don't worry, it is an excellent opportunity to practice your English\]

**【16+2 weeks teaching mode description】**

Week 1: Introduction to the Course (14/2)

Week 2: Introduction to Political Ecology (21/2)

Week 3: No class (28/2)

Week 4:Indigenous Peoples in the World (7/3)

Week 5:Guest Lecture 1 TBA (14/3)

Week 6: De-growth and Post-Development Theories (21/3)

Week 7: Guest Lecture 2 TBA (28/3)

Week 8: No class (4/4)

Week 9: Traditional Ecological Knowledge: What is TEK and why is it important? (11/4)

Week 10: Adaptive capacity, Nature Conservation and Natural Resource Management (18/4)

Week 11: Eco and Indigenous Tourism: Curse or Development Opportunity? (25/4)

Week 12: Preparation for the field trip and Fieldtrip (2/5)

Week 13: Global Climate Change and Sustainability (9/5)

Week 14: Land Grabbing, Mining, and Human Rights (16/5)

Week 15: Urban Political Ecology + Research Methods in PE (23/5)

Week 16: Wrap-up Lecture + deadlines (30/5)

Week 17: Reading week (no class)

Week 18: Reading week (no class)

methodologies.note: This course consists of lecturers which are both theoretical and empirical.
Students are required to lead seminars to practice their presentation skills.
We will visit an Indigenous Community in Taiwan
We will make ample use of media and visual materials during formal lectures.

grading.note:
Write a essay and present it during class – choose a theme related to political ecology (a topic list will be provided) – 40%.
Photo-based essay during the fieldtrip – 20%
Assignment on the guest lecture in the class – 10%
In each class we will have class debates, video assignments, or other forms of class involvement.
Everyone is required to attend the lectures and seminars, unless you have a valid reason not to come.

prerequisite: ◎Available for junior and senior year B.A. program students (Doctoral program courses excepted) and M.A. program students.
